Through skill and cunning you know exactly where to strike someone to hurt them best and how to do it with subtlety.  Starting at 1st level, once per turn you can deal an extra 1d6 damage to a single creature when you hit them.  However, you must have advantage on the roll for this to be attempted, and the attack has to be with either a ranged weapon or one that has the finesse trait.


    However, if there is an enemy of the target within 5 feet of target, and that enemy is not @Compendium[undertaking.conditions.3CQC3JEY2C3Y721F]{Incapacitated} in some way, and you don’t have disadvantage on the roll in some way, you may also make a Sneak Attack.


    The amount of damage that a Sneak Attack deals increases as you gain levels in the Rogue class, as shown in the table below:

    You can do more than just deal damage with a Sneak Attack, however.  As your Sneak Attack grows more deadly, you gain the ability to apply conditions to target’s on a successful hit from your Sneak Attack.  When you make a Sneak Attack you can declare a condition that you have access to through this ability, to inflict on the target.  Should you successfully hit, the target takes damage and must make a Constitution (Save) check (listed below), and if it fails, now has that condition.


    The conditions that you can apply, and the damage from your Sneak Attack needed to use it is shown below:

The DC for this ability is: 

 

8 + your proficiency modifier + half the number of die on your Sneak Attack (minimum 1) 

 


    With the exception of @Compendium[undertaking.conditions.R54LQEKSDXNQ3N75]{Bleeding}, a condition affecting a creature from this ability lasts 1 turn.


    It should also be noted, that every 2 levels of a class other than Rogue counts for a single Rogue level in regards to calculating what damage your Sneak Attack deals.
